source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: The effects of the test variables and gaseous species on test reproducibility are minimized by the addition of a prefilming step at 410°C for 4 to 8 h before exposing the test samples to a higher nodule-forming temperature.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: The prefilming treatment reduces the degree of nodular corrosion

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: A test involving a prefilming step at 410°C/1500 psig (102 bars) for 8 h and a nodule sensitivity step at 510°C/1500 psig (102 bars) for 16 h

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: A test involving a prefilming step at 410°C/1500 psig (102 bars) for 8 h and a nodule sensitivity step at 510°C/1500 psig (102 bars) for 16 h

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: Good reproducibility of the 410/510°C two-step test was demonstrated over 40 test runs using control samples.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: Good reproducibility of the 410/510°C two-step test was demonstrated over 40 test runs using control samples.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: Nodular corrosion of the type experienced in BWRs cannot be reproduced in the laboratory at BWR operating temperature (~300°C) and pressure (1000 psig or 69 bars)

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: ASTM Practice for Aqueous Corrosion Testing of Samples of Zirconium and Zirconium Alloys (G 2) in 400°C, 1500 psig (104 bars) steam for 72 h

evidence_span: 500°C/1500 psig (102 bars)/24 h autoclave steam test reported by Johnson [5] and Urquhart et al. [6] does produce nodular oxide resembling that observed in BWRs

evidence_span: hourly refreshed autoclave tests at 500°C, Bentley [8] also found significant variations in the nodular corrosion behavior of Zircaloy samples of the same batch

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: 500°C, 1500 psig (102 bars) test

evidence_span: A two-step steam test involving a reproducibility enhancing prefilming step at 410°C and a nodular sensitivity step at 510°C was developed in 1979

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: A two-step steam test involving a reproducibility enhancing prefilming step at 410°C and a nodular sensitivity step at 510°C was developed in 1979

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: developmental tests to define test parameters were carried out using a 1-L autoclave

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: A 20-L autoclave utilizing a tube furnace as the heat source was employed to test up to 200 to 300 samples in a single run

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk2
evidence_span: All three systems utilize a back-pressure regulator to control the ytem pressure and a high-pressure pulsating pump  crculat te water/seam.Chromel alumel (K-type) thermocouples were used to measure the test temperature. At least two and as many as four thermocouples were used to assure temperature uniformity within the test zone. The test temperature within the test zone in all three systems were controlled within $\pm 2 . 2 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ at 480 to $5 3 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ .

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk2
evidence_span: The 1-L autoclave normally achieved a temperature accuracy of $\pm 1 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ and remained stable throughout a run.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk2
evidence_span: A set of six Zircaloy-2 tubes $( 3 . 6 ~ \mathrm { m } )$ representing a broad spectrum of nodular corrosion resistance was employed for parametric studies.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk2
evidence_span: Samples cut from the tubes were 1.7 or $2 . 5 \mathrm { { c m } }$ long and $1 . 2 \mathrm { { c m } }$ diameter.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk2
evidence_span: Samples were etched in a solution containing 2 to $5 \ \mathrm { v o l \% }$ concentrated HF, $\sim 4 5 \mathrm { v o l } \% \ \mathrm { H N O } _ { 3 }$ , and the remaining distilled water for 2 to 4 min to produce a shiny metallic surface.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk2
evidence_span: Approximately $5 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { { m } }$ thick material was removed from both the inner and outer surfaces.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk2
evidence_span: Samples were then etched in the ${ \bf H } { \bf F } / { \bf H } { \bf N } { \bf O } _ { 3 } / { \bf H } _ { 2 } { \bf O }$ solution for 2 min to remove approximately 30 to $4 0 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$ of metal from each surface.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk2
evidence_span: Dissolved oxygen up to $\sim 4 0$ ppm was added to the influent water by bubbling atmospheric pressure oxygen or oxygen/argon mixed gas through the feedwater tank.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk2
evidence_span: Hydrogen gas solubility in water at room temperature is only \~ 1 ppm.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk2
evidence_span: Addition of hydrogen up to an estimated concentration of over 200 ppm was accomplished by corroding sacrificial low oxygen sponge-grade zirconium strips

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk2
evidence_span: the time required to heat the autoclave from room temperature to ${ 5 0 0 ^ { \circ } } \mathbf { C }$ was $2 1 / 4$ to ${ \bf 2 1 } / { \bf 2 \ h }$ .

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk2
evidence_span: The flow rate for the 1-L autoclave was set at $1 0 ~ \mathrm { c m } ^ { 3 } / \mathrm { m i n }$ unless specified otherwise.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk2
evidence_span: The tests were conducted in 1500 psig (102 bars) steam at 480, 490, 500, 510, 520, and ${ 5 3 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C } }$ for $\mathbf { 1 6 \ h }$ using the operation procedure highlighted in Table 1.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk2
evidence_span: nodular corrosion does not develop on Zircaloy-2 at ${ \bf 4 8 0 ^ { \circ } C }$ or below.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk2
evidence_span: A few tiny oxide nodules can be observed on the most corrosion susceptible sample, A6, at ${ \bf 4 9 0 ^ { \circ } C } .$

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk2
evidence_span: At ${ 5 0 0 ^ { \circ } } \mathbf { C }$ , samples A1 to A4 remained resistant to nodular corrosion, while samples A5 and A6 became susceptible to nodular corrosion.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk2
evidence_span: Both the nodule number density and size can be seen to increase with increasing test temperature.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk2
evidence_span: The large nodules at $5 3 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ show some spallation.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk2
evidence_span: Thus test temperatures at 500 to ${ 5 2 0 ^ { \circ } } \mathbf { C }$ appear to be optimized for test sensitivity.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk2
evidence_span: This threshold temperature is approximately $4 8 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ for Zircaloy-2 in 1500 psig (102 bars) steam (Fig. 2).

evidence_span: With preadded water of 200 cm³ or less, the steam pressure lagged behind the saturation values

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk7
evidence_span: The nodular corrosion susceptibility of Zircaloy in ~500°C steam is sensitive to test parameters such as temperature, pressure, and operating procedure.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_023_chunk7
evidence_span: A test temperature of 510°C or higher, and a pressure of about 1500 psig (102 bars), appear to provide adequate nodular corrosion sensitivity for Zircaloy, particularly Zircaloy-2.
